Title: About
Body:
### About the Local Environmental Observer Network

LEO is a network of local observers and topic experts who share knowledge about unusual animal, environment, and weather events. With LEO, you can connect with others in your community, share observations, raise awareness, and find answers about significant environmental events. You can also engage with topic experts in many different organizations and become part of a broader observer community.

[Visit us at leonetwork.org](https://www.leonetwork.org)

### About the LEO Field Reporter App

The LEO Field Reporter app is the easiest way to contribute to the LEO Network. It is designed to work without a network connection, so it's usable wherever you are witnessing unusual environmental events.
BodyHtml:
About the Local Environmental Observer Network

LEO is a network of local observers and topic experts who share knowledge about unusual animal, environment, and weather events. With LEO, you can connect with others in your community, share observations, raise awareness, and find answers about significant environmental events. You can also engage with topic experts in many different organizations and become part of a broader observer community.

Visit us at leonetwork.org

About the LEO Field Reporter App

The LEO Field Reporter app is the easiest way to contribute to the LEO Network. It is designed to work without a network connection, so it's usable wherever you are witnessing unusual environmental events.

Localizations.Title: Acerca De
Localizations.Body:
### Acerca de la Red Local de Observadores Ambientales

LEO es una red de observadores locales y expertos en temas que comparten conocimientos sobre animales inusuales, medio ambiente y eventos meteorológicos. Con LEO, puede conectarse con otras personas de su comunidad, compartir observaciones, crear conciencia y encontrar respuestas sobre eventos ambientales significativos. También puede interactuar con expertos en temas en muchas organizaciones diferentes y formar parte de una comunidad de observadores más amplia.

[Visítenos en leonetwork.org](https://www.leonetwork.org)

### Acerca de la aplicación LEO Field Reporter

La aplicación LEO Field Reporter es la forma más fácil de contribuir a la Red LEO. Está diseñado para funcionar sin una conexión de red, por lo que se puede usar dondequiera que sea testigo de eventos ambientales inusuales.
Localizations.BodyHtml:
Acerca de la Red Local de Observadores Ambientales

LEO es una red de observadores locales y expertos en temas que comparten conocimientos sobre animales inusuales, medio ambiente y eventos meteorológicos. Localizations.Title: Environ
Localizations.Body:
### À propos du Réseau local d'observateurs de l'environnement

LEO est un réseau d'observateurs locaux et d'experts en matière de sujets qui partagent des connaissances sur les animaux inhabituels, l'environnement et les événements météorologiques. Avec LEO, vous pouvez communiquer avec d'autres membres de votre communauté, partager des observations, sensibiliser les gens et trouver des réponses au sujet d'événements environnementaux importants. Vous pouvez également communiquer avec des experts en matière de sujets dans de nombreuses organisations différentes et faire partie d'une communauté d'observateurs plus large.

[Visitez-nous à leonetwork.org](https://www.leonetwork.org)

### À propos de l'application LEO Field Reporter

L'application LEO Field Reporter est le moyen le plus simple de contribuer au réseau LEO. Il est conçu pour fonctionner sans connexion réseau, de sorte qu'il est utilisable partout où vous êtes témoin d'événements environnementaux inhabituels.

Title: Help
Body:
### Enrolling in the LEO Network

### What if you forgot your password?

### Tips for Making Great Observations

#### Write a good headline
Your headline (or title) is the most important part of your observation. It is the first thing someone will see when they view your observation in search results, on maps, in emails, and so on. It should summarize your observation in a few words, and should orient someone to your observation even if they are seeing it for the first time. Example of good headlines are:

- European aspens still in summer foliage in mid-October
- Sea lion sighted in Barrow
- Rain in Rovaniemi in November

You headline should include a clue as to why your observation is unusual. You can add more details in the description section of your observation, but it should be apparent from the headline that something unexpected has been observed. Note that you do not have to include the place or date of your observation, as there are dedicated fields for that. However, sometimes you will want to include that information if it helps to make your headline better. In the above example about rain in Rovaniemi, it is helpful to say where and when - rain itself is not unusual, but rain in November in Rovaniemi is unusual, and important.

#### Include photos

After your headline, photos are the most important part of your observation. If at all possible, you should try to take at least one photo when you are making your observation. Ideally, you might take 2 or 3, from different angles and at different distances. If you are making an observation after-the-fact, you may not have access to photos of the actual thing you observed. In that case, you might ask others if they have photos that you could post with your observation, always getting permission first, of course.

#### Choose categories carefully

LEO has three groups of categories that are used to describe your observation:

- **Natural Environment**, which contains options such as Weather, Fish, and Land Mammals.
- **Unusual or Unexpected Event**, which contains options such as Extreme Temperature, Death/Decline/Die-off, and Wildfire.
- **Impact on Human Environment**, which contain options such as Health, Economic Impact, and Food Security.

You may choose as many categories as you wish, and you aren't required to choose categories in all three groups. As a guideline, however, it is usually best to choose a small number of categories (up to 2 or 3) in each group. The categories you choose are used to help others find your observation. By choosing too many categories, you dilute the ones that are most applicable, so it is not a good idea to simply check everything that could possibly relate to your observation.

#### Fill in the details

When you make an observation, you are asked to describe it in words. You may include as long of a description as you want, but it might be enough to include just three or four sentences. You should try to establish the following with your description:

- What is the context of your observation? What were you doing when you made the observation? For example, you might say that you were fishing, or hiking, or driving when you made your observation.
- What did you witness? You may have already established this in your headline, but this is an opportunity to provide more detail.
- What makes you think it is unusual? For example, if you have lived in a place for a long time and have never seen it, it probably qualifies as unusual. You might include a mention of what you expected to see. For example, "we expect the lake to be frozen over by mid-November, but this year there's still open water."
- Finally, does it have an impact on your life or the life of your family or community? For example, "the frozen lake is an important means of transportation for us in the winter, but we can't use it while the ice is still thin."

It can be challenging to make a good observation, because many things we witness are either too insignificant to be noteworthy, or so significant that they are common knowledge. But once you start keeping an eye out for good observations, you will see them everywhere. There's no single right way to make an observation, but these guidelines should help you get started.
BodyHtml:
Enrolling in the LEO Network

What if you forgot your password?

Tips for Making Great Observations

Write a good headline

Your headline (or title) is the most important part of your observation. It is the first thing someone will see when they view your observation in search results, on maps, in emails, and so on. It should summarize your observation in a few words, and should orient someone to your observation even if they are seeing it for the first time. Example of good headlines are:

  • European aspens still in summer foliage in mid-October
  • Sea lion sighted in Barrow
  • Rain in Rovaniemi in November

You headline should include a clue as to why your observation is unusual. You can add more details in the description section of your observation, but it should be apparent from the headline that something unexpected has been observed. Note that you do not have to include the place or date of your observation, as there are dedicated fields for that. However, sometimes you will want to include that information if it helps to make your headline better. In the above example about rain in Rovaniemi, it is helpful to say where and when - rain itself is not unusual, but rain in November in Rovaniemi is unusual, and important.

Include photos

After your headline, photos are the most important part of your observation. If at all possible, you should try to take at least one photo when you are making your observation. Ideally, you might take 2 or 3, from different angles and at different distances. If you are making an observation after-the-fact, you may not have access to photos of the actual thing you observed. In that case, you might ask others if they have photos that you could post with your observation, always getting permission first, of course.

Choose categories carefully

LEO has three groups of categories that are used to describe your observation:

  • Natural Environment, which contains options such as Weather, Fish, and Land Mammals.
  • Unusual or Unexpected Event, which contains options such as Extreme Temperature, Death/Decline/Die-off, and Wildfire.
  • Impact on Human Environment, which contain options such as Health, Economic Impact, and Food Security.

You may choose as many categories as you wish, and you aren't required to choose categories in all three groups. As a guideline, however, it is usually best to choose a small number of categories (up to 2 or 3) in each group. The categories you choose are used to help others find your observation. By choosing too many categories, you dilute the ones that are most applicable, so it is not a good idea to simply check everything that could possibly relate to your observation.

Fill in the details

When you make an observation, you are asked to describe it in words. You may include as long of a description as you want, but it might be enough to include just three or four sentences. You should try to establish the following with your description:

  • What is the context of your observation? What were you doing when you made the observation? For example, you might say that you were fishing, or hiking, or driving when you made your observation.
  • What did you witness? You may have already established this in your headline, but this is an opportunity to provide more detail.
  • What makes you think it is unusual? For example, if you have lived in a place for a long time and have never seen it, it probably qualifies as unusual. You might include a mention of what you expected to see. For example, "we expect the lake to be frozen over by mid-November, but this year there's still open water."
  • Finally, does it have an impact on your life or the life of your family or community? For example, "the frozen lake is an important means of transportation for us in the winter, but we can't use it while the ice is still thin."

It can be challenging to make a good observation, because many things we witness are either too insignificant to be noteworthy, or so significant that they are common knowledge. But once you start keeping an eye out for good observations, you will see them everywhere. There's no single right way to make an observation, but these guidelines should help you get started.
